refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: A GtkStatusbar is usually placed along the bottom of an application's main GtkWindow. It may provide a regular commentary of the application's status (as is usually the case in a web browser, for example), or may be used to simply output a message when the status changes, (when an upload is complete in an FTP client, for example). It may also have a resize grip (a triangular area in the lower right corner) which can be clicked on to resize the window containing the statusbar.
Status bars in Gtk+ maintain a stack of messages. The message at the top of the each bar's stack is the one that will currently be displayed.

Any messages added to a statusbar's stack must specify a context_id that is used to uniquely identify the source of a message. This context_id can be generated by gtk_statusbar_get_context_id(), given a message and the statusbar that it will be added to. Note that messages are stored in a stack, and when choosing which message to display, the stack structure is adhered to, regardless of the context identifier of a message.
Status bars are created using gtk_statusbar_new().
Messages are added to the bar's stack with gtk_statusbar_push().

The message at the top of the stack can be removed using gtk_statusbar_pop(). A message can be removed from anywhere in the stack if its message_id was recorded at the time it was added. This is done using gtk_statusbar_remove().

refsect2.title: GtkStatusbar
refsect2.para: Contains private data that should be modified with the functions described below.

refsect2.title: gtk_statusbar_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new GtkStatusbar ready for messages.

listitem.simpara: the new GtkStatusbar.

refsect2.title: gtk_statusbar_get_context_id ()
refsect2.para: Returns a new context identifier, given a description of the actual context.

listitem.simpara: a GtkStatusbar.
textual description of what context the new message is being used in.
an integer id.

refsect2.title: gtk_statusbar_push ()
refsect2.para: Pushes a new message onto a statusbar's stack.

listitem.simpara: a GtkStatusbar.
the message's context id, as returned by gtk_statusbar_get_context_id().
the message to add to the statusbar.
the message's new message id for use with gtk_statusbar_remove().

refsect2.title: gtk_statusbar_pop ()
refsect2.para: Removes the message at the top of a GtkStatusBar's stack.

listitem.simpara: a GtkStatusBar.
a context identifier.

refsect2.title: gtk_statusbar_remove ()
refsect2.para: Forces the removal of a message from a statusbar's stack. The exact context_id and message_id must be specified.

listitem.simpara: a GtkStatusBar.
a context identifier.
a message identifier, as returned by gtk_statusbar_push().

refsect2.title: gtk_statusbar_set_has_resize_grip ()
refsect2.para: Sets whether the statusbar has a resize grip. TRUE by default.

listitem.simpara: a GtkStatusBar.
TRUE to have a resize grip.

refsect2.title: gtk_statusbar_get_has_resize_grip ()
refsect2.para: Returns whether the statusbar has a resize grip.

listitem.simpara: a GtkStatusBar.
TRUE if the statusbar has a resize grip.

refsect2.title: The :has-resize-grip property
refsect2.para: Whether the statusbar has a grip for resizing the toplevel window.

refsect2.title: The :shadow-type style property
refsect2.para: Style of bevel around the statusbar text.

refsect2.title: The ::text-popped signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkStatusbar *statusbar, guint context_id, gchar *text, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Is emitted whenever a new message is popped off a statusbar's stack.

listitem.simpara: the object which received the signal.
the context id of the relevant message/statusbar.
the message that was just popped.
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

refsect2.title: The ::text-pushed signal
refsect2.programlisting: void user_function (GtkStatusbar *statusbar, guint context_id, gchar *text, gpointer user_data) : Run Last
refsect2.para: Is emitted whenever a new message gets pushed onto a statusbar's stack.

listitem.simpara: the object which received the signal.
the context id of the relevant message/statusbar.
the message that was pushed.
user data set when the signal handler was connected.

listitem.para: another way of reporting information to the user.
